content.body: Chrome has started development on Private Network Access for WebSockets, which is going to require a preflight. As discussed in the following few messages after https://github.com/whatwg/websockets/issues/16#issuecomment-1926609805, we will probably need new `Access-Control-Allow-WebSocket` and `Access-Control-Request-WebSocket` headers. What's the right forum to propose and discuss those?
content.formatted_body: Chrome has started development on Private Network Access for WebSockets, which is going to require a preflight. As discussed in the following few messages after https://github.com/whatwg/websockets/issues/16#issuecomment-1926609805, we will probably need new Access-Control-Allow-WebSocket and Access-Control-Request-WebSocket headers. What's the right forum to propose and discuss those?

content.body: Adam Rice: Any reason not to just use the https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues tracker?

content.body: TabAtkins: algorithm="..." values in Bikeshed are just for disambiguation purposes, right?
content.formatted_body: TabAtkins: algorithm="..." values in Bikeshed are just for disambiguation purposes, right?

content.body: * TabAtkins: algorithm="..." values in Bikeshed are just for disambiguation purposes, right? See https://github.com/whatwg/url/pull/826 for context. I guess I'll leave it unmerged for a bit so you can review. Fortunately adding these didn't reveal any variable name errors.

content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> TabAtkins: algorithm="..." values in Bikeshed are just for disambiguation purposes, right?

Yes, tho they're also required to have variable colors kick in
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
TabAtkins: algorithm="..." values in Bikeshed are just for disambiguation purposes, right?
Yes, tho they're also required to have variable colors kick in

content.body: TabAtkins: right, that's why it's worth adding them. (Although I also added them for algorithms that don't contain any variables, mainly for consistency.)
content.formatted_body: TabAtkins: right, that's why it's worth adding them. (Although I also added them for algorithms that don't contain any variables, mainly for consistency.)

content.body: I also use them for some useful styling, the little gray border, which I'm planning to add to the bikeshed stylesheet. Might want to look into putting it in whatwg as well
Seems to really help in algorithm heavy sections to know the bounds of the text
TabAtkins: does the PR look okay btw?
content.formatted_body: TabAtkins: does the PR look okay btw?
